metadata.title: Dysphagia Assessment  Endoscopic Evaluation
area of specialty: v oice and v oice disorders
description: Endoscopic evaluations of swallowing are procedures in which laryngoscopes are utilized to visualize laryngeal anatomy, physiology, and/or swallowing function from inside the pharyngeal cavity.(1,2,3) These evaluations can be used to supplement or substitute for a modified barium swallow study (MBSS). Types of endoscopic evaluations for dysphagia include fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES), FEES with sensory testing (FEESST), and rigid laryngoscopic examination. These tests can be performed by a specially trained speech-language pathologist (SLP) or an otolaryngologist (ENT)

In addition to an SLP and an ENT, a gastroenterologist might screen patients for laryngeal dysfunction during an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy(4) –In a study conducted in Italy in which 2 gastroenterologists were trained by ENTs to recognize laryngeal damage during the initial stage of an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, researchers concluded that given training and experience in recognizing laryngeal damage, gastroenterologists might be able to detect signs of reflux or premalignancy in the larynx with a flexible video gastroscope(4) –If a gastroenterologist does suspect laryngeal involvement based on an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, the patient should be referred to an ENT for further workup
indications: An endoscopic evaluation is indicated for patients with dysphagia, voice disorders, or other pathologies of the larynx and esophagus; also indicated for patients suspected of having these disorders(2)

Indicated in certain patients with dysphagia based on the outcome of an in-depth clinical swallowing examination (CSE), which should always precede an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing in patients with dysphagia(1,5) –For detailed information on an in-depth  CSE, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: In-depth  Bedside Swallow Examination (Adults) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709037 and Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: In-depth  Bedside Swallow Examination (Pediatrics) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709064 –In a study conducted in Turkey, researchers compared the effectiveness of a CSE, FEES, and electromyographic evaluation of swallowing in identifying dysphagia. Subjects included 24 patients who had a stroke within the previous 3 months. For the CSE, patients swallowed 10 mL of water and oxygen saturation was monitored by pulse oximetry. Researchers calculated a “Bedside Dysphagia Score” by giving patients a point for each sign/symptom of dysphagia observed during the CSE (0–2 was considered normal swallow, 3–6 was considered dysphagia). Researchers found that a BDS score of 3+ was positively correlated with dysphagia identified by the FEES and the electromyographic evaluations. Researchers concluded that the CSE was as effective in identifying dysphagia post stroke as the FEES and electromyographic evaluations; however, they concluded that best practice for adequately evaluating  the nature of dysphagia was to perform a combination of a CSE and an instrumental examination(47) –In a study conducted in Denmark, researchers found that a FEES was not superior to a clinical, noninstrumental examination of swallowing (i.e., CSE) in identifying dysphagia in terms of the number of cases of aspiration pneumonia that developed in a group of patients with acquired brain injury (i.e., stroke, traumatic brain injury, anoxia).(46) Over the course of 2 years, 138 patients from a national neurorehabilitation center were randomized into a FEES assessment group or a Facial-Oral  Tract Therapy (FOTT) assessment group. FOTT is a comprehensive program that provides a structured assessment and treatment for disturbances of facial muscles, speech-  and swallowing-related  jaw movements, breathing, swallowing, and the voice. The FOTT assessment is a clinical, noninstrumental examination of swallowing (i.e., CSE). Decision to initiate oral intake for these patients was based entirely on the single assessment; none of these patients had both types of swallowing assessments. Of the 138 patients included in the study, 16 developed pneumonia (4 FOTT/12 FEES); however, 9 were excluded from analysis because 6 developed pneumonia before oral intake was initiated and 3 had a clinical diagnosis of pneumonia but no radiological signs. Of the 7 included in analysis, 3 patients assessed by FOTT and 4 patients assessed by FEES developed aspiration pneumonia. For this reason, researchers concluded that there was no significant difference between the FOTT and FEES assessments in ability to identify dysphagia; however, the sample size was very small, resulting in low sensitivity(46) –In a study conducted in the United States in which 7 SLPs who were considered experts in dysphagia were asked to watch videos of CSEs and, later, videos of FEES results and make recommendations for oral intake based on these videos. The researcher found that there was no agreement between the CSE and FEES ratings with respect to pharyngeal and laryngeal anatomy and physiology or the characteristics of pharyngeal dysphagia, when present. Additionally, the researcher found that despite being unable to accurately determine the safety of the pharyngeal swallow in 60% of the CSE videos, the SLP still made a recommendation for an oral diet in 25% of these cases. The researcher who conducted this study strongly cautioned SLPs against making a determination about swallowing safety and appropriate oral diet in patients with pharyngeal dysphagia without completing an instrumental examination(50)
An endoscopic evaluation might be part of a comprehensive medical workup if a physician is attempting to determine a patient’s underlying diagnosis
A FEESST assesses both airway protection and bolus transport during swallowing and might be indicated for patients in whom sensory impairment of the larynx and/or vocal fold damage is suspected(6,7)

An endoscopic evaluation of swallowing might be indicated for patients who cannot participate in an MBS study, including: –Patients with safety issues related to radiation(1) –Pregnant women or other patients who should not be exposed to radiation(1) –Medically fragile patients who should not be transported or transferred, such as those with extensive thermal burn injuries(8)
In pediatric patients, flexible endoscopes can be used to visualize swallowed foreign bodies that become lodged in the cricopharyngeal sphincter and cause dysphagia (such as a toy or coin)(9)

CPT codes.92612:: flexible fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing by cine or video recording
CPT codes.92700:: unlisted otorhinolaryngological service or procedure (for flexible fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing without cine or video recording)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this procedure Indications for procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Prior to an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing, confirm that the patient is not on NPO status (nil per oris) awaiting a procedure; check with patient’s nurse prior to start of examination

Review patient’s chart and speak to the patient’s nurse and family members if possible to rule out food allergies; if a patient has a food allergy, confirm that the food and liquid used in the endoscopic evaluation do not contain these allergens(17)
In addition to food allergies, be aware of any religious or cultural dietary restrictions prior to giving the patient anything to eat(30)

Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (e.g., airborne, droplet, or contact precautions)(24,30)

Stay with the patient during the entirety of the endoscopic evaluation. Do NOT leave the patient alone with food or drink until the endoscopic evaluation is complete and the patient is determined to be safe for oral feeding(30)
Any clinician performing an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing should be trained in the Heimlich maneuver as well as CPR as choking is a possible complication of any swallowing evaluation(30)

indications for procedure: Dysphagia Dysphagia is defined as difficulty swallowing and/or a swallowing disorder(10,11) Complications of dysphagia include malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration and aspiration pneumonia, and death(10,12,13) There are two main categories of dysphagia(11) –Oropharyngeal dysphagia  (11,14,15) -Dysphagia that affects the oral phase only is referred to as oral dysphagia(16)  -Dysphagia that affects the pharyngeal phase only is referred to as pharyngeal dysphagia(16) -Dysphagia that affects both the oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow is referred to as oropharyngeal dysphagia(16) -Symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia include choking and/or coughing while eating and/or drinking, pocketing food in the cheeks, and loss of food or liquid from the mouth while attempting to swallow(10,14) –Esophageal dysphagia  (11,14,15) -Dysphagia resulting from an impairment of the esophagus or lower esophageal sphincter -Patients generally report symptoms such as regurgitation or heartburn(10,14,15) -Endoscopic evaluations are performed by gastroenterologists in cases of suspected esophageal dysphagia.(45) An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is a commonly used procedure in which an endoscope with a camera at the end is inserted into the patient’s esophagus to determine the etiology of esophageal dysfunction(45) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

Patients at risk for dysphagia Patients with the following diagnoses and risk factors are at an elevated risk for dysphagia: –Cervical osteophytes(11) –Ear, nose, throat, or maxillofacial surgery(17) –Advanced age(13,15,18) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in older adults, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Older Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T903600) –Head and neck cancer(10,11,19) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with head and neck cancer, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Patients with Head and Neck Cancer ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709050) –Infection(11) -Botulism(11) -Diphtheria(11) -Lyme disease(11) -Syphilis(11) –Neurological disease(10,11,17) -Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)(11,15,20) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with ALS, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708986) -Brainstem tumor(11) -Stroke(10,11,15,21,22,42) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients who have had a stroke, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Post-Stroke ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708770) -Dementia(10) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with dementia, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Dementia ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708935) -Dermatomyositis/polymyositis(11) (connective tissue disease marked by inflammation of the skin and/or muscles) -Multiple sclerosis(10,11,15) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Multiple Sclerosis ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708991) -Myasthenia gravis(11,15,23) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with myasthenia gravis, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Myasthenia Gravis in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709053 and Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Myasthenia Gravis in Children ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709054) -Myotonic dystrophy(11) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with myotonic dystrophy, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Myotonic Dystrophy in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709072) -Paraneoplastic syndrome(11) (collective signs and symptoms caused by material released from a tumor or in reaction to a tumor) -Parkinson disease(10,11,15) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with Parkinson disease, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Parkinson Disease ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708934) -Post-polio  syndrome(11) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in post-polio  syndrome, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Post-Polio Syndrome ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709062)  -Sarcoidosis(growth of small collections of inflammatory cells throughout the body)(11) -Traumatic brain injury(11,15) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of traumatic brain injury, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic) –Prior cervical or esophageal surgery(11,17) –Prolonged endotracheal intubation(18) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with tracheostomy, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Adults with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709084 and Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Children with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709082) –Zenker’s diverticulum (a pouch that forms at the junction of the pharynx and the esophagus)(11,15,41)

Aspiration Aspiration occurs when food or liquid penetrates below the level of the vocal folds(5) Normally, aspiration of food or liquid would provoke a cough reflex In many patients with dysphagia, the cough response is not elicited; this is known as silent aspiration(22,24,48) –The FEES and FEESST are very useful tests for identifying silent aspiration as it is impossible to determine if a patient is silently aspirating with a noninstrumental CSE alone(1,5,22,24,48)

contraindications for an endoscopic eval: Bilateral obstruction of the nasal passages(1)

an slp must have specific, specialized t: Each SLP is ethically responsible for attaining the proper level of training to provide an endoscopic evaluationcompetently(2)

The American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association (ASHA) recommends that each institution develop a written list ofcompetencies for performing endoscopic evaluations and ensure that an individual's competencies are verified in writing/maintained on file(2)
Some institutions have a credentialing or privileging process that is required
recommended training skills: ASHA recommends that SLPs undergo observation, practice under direct supervision, and independent practice withindirect supervision to be properly trained to conduct endoscopic assessments(25)

SLPs who intend to perform FEES and/or FEESST should take 10 to 14 hours of formal class training, observe 10 to 20FEES and/or FEESST procedures performed on patients with dysphagia, and practice passing the flexible endoscope atleast 25 times under direct supervision of a trained SLP or otolaryngologist(3)–In a study conducted in the United States, researchers found no difference in pass times for SLP graduatestudent clinicians who practiced passing transnasal endoscopes on a “human patient simulator” versus on anon-lifelike simulator(26)-However, both training groups were more confident and faster when performing the second endoscopy on a humanvolunteer as compared to the initial trial with a human volunteer(26)-Prior to passing a transnasal endoscope on a patient with dysphagia, SLPs should have adequate practice with nonpatienthuman volunteers(26)
per asha\u2019s policy, required areas o: Understanding of normal and abnormal aerodigestive physiology for respiration, airway protection, and swallow(25)
Ability to recognize pharyngeal and laryngeal anatomical landmarks as viewed endoscopically(25)
Ability to recognize altered pharyngeal and laryngeal anatomy as it relates to swallowing function(25)
Ability to recognize normal and abnormal changes in anatomy and physiology of the swallow over the life span(25)
Ability to identify the indications, precautions, and contraindications for endoscopic evaluations
Ability to identify all parts of a comprehensive endoscopic evaluation(25)
Ability to detect and interpret abnormal findings in terms of the underlying pharyngeal and laryngeal anatomy andpathophysiology(25)
Knowledge of appropriate treatment interventions, postural changes, and changes to bolus or method of delivery todetermine the effect on the swallow(25)
Ability to use the results of the examination to make appropriate diet and treatment recommendations for the patient(25)
Understanding of appropriate recommendations or referrals to other disciplines as needed(25)
Understanding of when the patient’s swallowing function should be reevaluated(25)
Ability to use endoscopy as a biofeedback and/or education tool with patients, family, and staff using the endoscopicimages either during or after the examination(25)

contraindications precautions to examina: Prior to an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing, confirm that the patient is not on NPO status (nil per oris) awaiting a procedure; check with patient’s nurse prior to start of examination

Review patient’s chart and speak to the patient’s nurse and family members if possible to rule out food allergies; if a patient has a food allergy, confirm that the food and liquid used in the endoscopic evaluation do not contain these allergens(17)
In addition to food allergies, be aware of any religious or cultural dietary restrictions prior to giving the patient anything to eat(30)

Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (e.g., airborne, droplet, or contact precautions)(24,30)

Stay with the patient during the entirety of the endoscopic evaluation. Do NOT leave the patient alone with food or drink until the endoscopic evaluation is complete and the patient is determined to be safe for oral feeding(30)

Any clinician performing an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing should be trained in the Heimlich maneuver as well as CPR as choking is a possible complication of any swallowing evaluation(30) examination(1) –Food and liquid trials may be given via spoon, cup sips, or syringe, as needed(3) –Refer to specific clinic/hospital protocol for specifics regarding food and liquid trials –Many different trials of varying amounts and consistencies should be administered during a FEES to most clearly define a patient’s dysphagia as well as give the SLP the opportunity to attempt compensatory strategies to improve swallowing safety(42) –Encourage outpatients/caregivers to bring foods that are particularly problematic –During food and liquid trials, the SLP and ENT observe both the patient and the video feed to evaluate the patient’s swallowing function –Prior to the swallow, premature spillover of any of the boluses into the pharynx or larynx can be observed(3) –Does the patient aspirate or penetrate before the swallow?(3) -Visible bolus material inside the trachea prior to the initiation of the swallow indicates aspiration(3)  -In a FEES or FEESST, the exact moment of passage of the bolus and movement of the structures during the swallow cannot be directly observed because tissue surrounds the end of the endoscopy, causing a brief state referred to as “white-out”(1,3) -The video screen/image of the larynx is completely blank during the white-out –Following the completion of the swallow, the presence of any bolus residue may indicate the nature of the pharyngeal swallowing impairment -Residue around the hypopharynx, valleculae, or pyriform sinuses can result from pharyngeal or laryngeal weakness as well as reduced pressure in the pharyngeal cavity during the swallow –Trial of compensatory strategies -Once dysphagia is identified via endoscopic evaluation, it might be appropriate for the SLP to guide the patient through different compensatory strategies in order to determine which strategies are the most beneficial for the patient’s swallowing function(1,3) -Initially, the SLP should attempt different food consistencies to determine if this eliminates aspiration (i.e., if the patient aspirates thin liquids, attempt nectar-thick  liquids)(1,3) -Other compensatory strategies that may be attempted during this time include: -Alternating solids and liquids(1) -Appropriate for patients with solid residue in the pharyngeal cavity after the swallow; a liquid wash can improve pharyngeal clearance -Chin down(1,36) -Appropriate for patients with delay of pharyngeal swallow, reduced tongue base retraction, reduced laryngeal closure, or reduced laryngeal elevation(36) -Chin up(1,36) -Appropriate for patients with tongue dysfunction, including poor anterior-posterior  propulsion of bolus(36) -Downward pressure with the spoon on the body of the tongue to assist initiation of swallow response -Dry swallows(1,36) -Having the patient swallow multiple times to clear as much residue as possible -Effortful swallow(1,36) -A maneuver intended to improve tongue base retraction and reduce residue buildup in the valleculae -Head rotation to right or left (rotate head towards the damaged side)(1,36) -Appropriate for patients with unilateral pharyngeal wall weakness, unilateral reduced laryngeal closure, or unilateral vocal fold paresis(36) -Attempt head turn to both sides to increase pharyngeal pressure in patients with cricopharyngeal dysfunction or reduced anterior movement of the larynx(36) -Liquids given by spoon only -Lying-down  position (on patient’s back or side)(36) -Appropriate for patients with reduced laryngeal elevation or bilateral pharyngeal wall weakness -Mendelsohn maneuver(36) -A technique that aims to improve laryngeal elevation and cricopharyngeal opening -Supraglottic swallow maneuver(36) -The goal of this maneuver is to close the vocal folds before and during the swallow to prevent aspiration -Super-supraglottic  swallow maneuver(36) -The goal of this maneuver is to close the entrance to the airway (laryngeal vestibule) before and during the swallow to prevent aspiration -For detailed information regarding treatments and compensatory strategies that can be attempted during an endoscopic evaluation, refer to the Clinical Reviews on these topics

Tracheostomy examination:  Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube?(17) –If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. For detailed information on assessment of patients with tracheostomies, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Children  with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709082 and Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Adults with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709084 –When the patient has an uncapped tracheostomy tube, subglottic pressure is reduced and the strength of the swallow is altered(30) -Complete Passy-Muir  tracheostomy and ventilator swallowing and speaking valve evaluation prior to an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing. (For detailed information on assessment for and treatment with the Passy-Muir valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and Speaking Valve ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708919)

Special tests specific to procedure –Laryngeal/oropharyngeal examination: An endoscopic evaluation allows the examiner to observe the oropharyngeal and laryngeal structures at rest and in motion.(1) (For detailed information regarding a FEES, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Fiberoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing (FEES) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709038) -Is the laryngeal mucosa intact? -Does the tissue appear healthy? (pinkish white) -Is there any edema or anatomical changes due to surgery or radiation therapy?(1,19) -Is there evidence of acid reflux damage? (white or yellow burns) -Pooling secretions -Note the status of standing secretions in the hypopharynx as well as the frequency and effectiveness of spontaneous swallowing(1,25) -Patients with excessive pooling of secretions have increased risk of aspiration(1,25) -Is there penetration or aspiration of saliva? -In a study conducted in Germany of 100 first-time  stroke patients admitted within 24 hours of symptom onset who underwent FEES, researchers found that even when corrected for age and severity of symptoms upon admission, the finding of saliva penetration or aspiration on the FEES exam increased the risk of subsequent orotracheal intubation 10-fold(22) -Observe the vocal folds at rest and in motion -Have the patient breathe normally, hold his or her breath, sustain phonation and speak at the word, sentence, or conversation level as able to examine vocal fold function(3) -Is the patient able to maintain vocal fold closure? -Reduced ability to maintain vocal fold closure increases a patient’s risk of aspiration(25) -If vocal fold bowing, paresis, hemorrhage, or other pathology is evident upon examination, refer to ENT for additional workup –Sensory testing: Indicated when there is known or suspected damage to one or both vocal folds(7) -Sensory testing of the laryngopharyngeal structures may be completed in conjunction with a FEES; in this case, the test is referred to as a FEESST(3,6,25) -Sensory testing of the laryngopharyngeal structures is performed because reduced sensation has been shown to be a predictor of laryngeal penetration and aspiration in endoscopic evaluations of swallowing(6,37,38) -If impaired sensation is discovered during the sensory testing portion of a FEESST, the examiner might alter his or her test protocol in anticipation of likely penetration or aspiration -If sensory testing is being performed, it should be completed prior to giving the patient food or liquid trials(6) -In order to test a patient’s laryngopharyngeal sensory thresholds, the examiner must utilize specialized endoscopic equipment that delivers 50 ms wide air pulses to the aryepiglottic folds(3,6) -The air pulses are delivered to the aryepiglottic folds because they are innervated by the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve(6) -The air pulses should elicit the laryngeal adductor reflex in a patient whose superior laryngeal nerve is intact(6) -The greater the pressure of the air pulse required to elicit the reflex, the more impaired the laryngeal sensation(3,6) -In a study conducted in the United States in which 1,340 FEESSTs were performed on 1,076 adults with dysphagia over a period of 4 1/2 years, sensory deficits were defined as: none (sensory threshold of < 4.0 mm Hg air pulse  pressure), moderate (sensory threshold of 4.1 to 6.0 mm Hg air pulse pressure), or severe (sensory threshold of > 6.1 mm Hg air pulse pressure)(6) -In a study conducted in the United States, results from 81 patients who had undergone FEESST for vocal fold immobility during the period 2000–2003  were collected and reviewed; researchers found that as laryngeal sensation decreased, the probability of pooling, penetration, and aspiration during swallowing increased(7)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -The first step in an endoscopic evaluation is to gather the patient’s medical history and review his or her medical records(1,17,30,31) -An interview with the patient and/or family members/caregivers might be appropriate to gather a detailed history of the symptoms and presentation of patient’s dysphagia(32) -Does the patient have a diagnosis that places him or her at elevated risk for dysphagia?(32) -Is the patient NPO? If so, how long has the patient been NPO?(30)

course of treatment.medical management: Note current and previous management of medical diagnosis (e.g., stroke, head and neck cancer); do any of the medical treatments put the patient at an elevated risk for dysphagia? Chemotherapy and radiation may result in xerostomia (dry mouth);(18) xerostomia is frequently associated with dysphagia(15,18,19) Current or previous ear, nose, throat, maxillofacial, cervical or esophageal surgery/procedures may place the patient at elevated risk(11,17)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Review patient’s medical record to determine if a CSE or any instrumental evaluation of the swallow was completed during a previous hospital stay or outpatient visit(30)
Review neuroimaging (e.g., MRI and CT scan) results
Review patient’s recent chest X-rays;  be aware of increasing infiltrates in the lungs
Bedbound patients who have aspirated food or liquids during swallowing sometimes present with heterogeneous

opacities on chest Xrays;  the material is generally aspirated into the posterior segments of the upper lobes of the lung or into the superior and posterior basal segments of the lower lobes of the lungs(33)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help Occasionally patients and family members develop their own strategies for managing dysphagia (such as using gravies with all meats or chopping up the food into very small pieces) Patients with prior histories of dysphagia may already be using an altered diet prior to admission(34) Ask the patient and/or caregiver what types of food or drink the patient prefers and/or avoids at home(34)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Document whether the patient has had a psychiatric or psychological treatment

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)(30) -with specific foods? -with specific meals? -only halfway through meals? -when fatigued? -when he or she is distracted or having a meal with a group of people?(13)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms -For patients who complain of difficulty swallowing, what exactly is the problem with swallowing? -Does food stick in the throat?(15) -Does the patient cough and/or choke while eating or drinking? -Is there pain associated with swallowing?
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -When did the symptoms of dysphagia first present?(35) -How frequently does the patient experience symptoms of dysphagia?(35)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Does difficulty swallowing saliva and/or secretions interfere with patient’s ability to sleep? Does xerostomia interfere with patient’s ability to sleep? -Document number of wakings/night
history of present illness.respiratory status: Patients with a compromised respiratory status are at higher risk of complications due to dysphagia(30,34) -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula?(17) -Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube?(17)  -Does the patient require ventilator support? -Patients who require ventilator support are at an elevated risk for aspiration during swallowing(30) -Patients who have been orally intubated should be extubated 2448  hours prior to completion of an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing to allow for the reduction of laryngeal edema and improved vocal fold function(43,44)Briefly assess the patient’s psychosocial status -Has anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, or another mental health diagnosis ever been diagnosed in the patient? -How does the patient relate to his or her surroundings? Is the patient overly emotional, anxious, or fearful? -If there are concerns regarding the patient’s psychosocial status and he or she is not currently under the care of a psychiatrist or other mental health professional, a referral for further workup may be appropriateBriefly assess the patient’s hearing abilities -Does the patient require hearing aids or cochlear implants? If yes, does he or she wear them as recommended? -If the patient appears to have impaired hearing and is not already receiving audiological services, refer to an audiologist for full workup Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of oropharyngeal dysphagia?(30)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient or family/caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencing, such as reflux, oral pain, or throat pain Does the patient have a history (recent or remote) of hoarseness, cough, throat clearing, heartburn, lump in the throat, regurgitation, pain when talking, smoking, or alcohol use?(27)

social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -With whom does the patient live (e.g., caregivers, family members)?(17) -Who prepares the patient’s food? -Does the patient often eat in restaurants or at the homes of friends or family members? -Patients with dysphagia might need to eat their meals alone or in silence to prevent distraction, which can increase risk of aspiration -Patients who require an altered diet often require assistance with food preparation from family members and/or caregiver(17) -Is the patient receiving nutritional supplements orally or nonorally?(30) -Is there a feeding tube present?(17,30) -Does the patient require feeding assistance at home?(13,17) Does the patient require assistance with food preparation?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: A patient requiring ventilator support via tracheostomy tube might still be appropriate for an endoscopic evaluation; refer to specific clinic/hospital protocol and physician orders(3)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Patients must have adequate muscle tone to hold the head in an upright position to accept food and liquid trials(1) –If the patient is unable to independently hold his or her head upright, adequate positioning might be achieved through use of pillows, wedges, or adaptive wheelchair; use input from physical/occupational therapy as well as clinical judgment to determine patient’s appropriateness for PO intake
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Briefly assess communication skills of the patient prior to completion of the endoscopic evaluation –If the patient appears to have speech, language, fluency, or other communication deficits, it may be appropriate to complete a full evaluation of speech and language skills
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: An extensive oral mechanism examination should be completed prior to or asAbnormalities of the buccal and facial muscles may indicate damage to cranial nerve (CN) VII(17) -Is the face symmetrical at rest? -Is the face symmetrical while making movements (smiling, raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes)? -Are there any abnormal movements (twitching, spasms, grimacing)? -Is the patient able to manage his or her secretions?(12,30) -Is the patient’s facial sensation intact?(17) -The patient needs to have adequate sensation of the facial muscles to feel and retrieve any residue during a meal -Is the patient drooling or mouth breathing?(12,17) -Does the patient present with slurred speech/dysarthria?(17,34) -If the patient presents with dysarthria, he or she might be appropriate for a full speech/language evaluation following completion of the endoscopic evaluation -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAbnormalities of the labial muscles may indicate damage to CN VII(17,32) -Are the lips symmetrical at rest? -Are the lips symmetrical during movements? -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to completely seal his or her lips during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly(31) -Is the strength normal? -Labial weakness can result in anterior loss of bolus -Is lip tissue healthy? -Is there any scarring or cleft? -Is the patient’s labial sensation intact?(17) -If a patient has reduced sensation of one or both lips, the patient is at risk for anterior loss or pocketing of the food on the side of reduced sensationAbnormalities of the tongue might indicate damage to CN XII(17,32) -Is the tongue normal in appearance? -Any atrophy? -Any tremors present? -Any discolorations? -Any bleeding? -Patients with dry mouth (xerostomia) as a result of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or other medication side effects may present with dry, cracked tongue tissue or a white/yellow coating on the tongue -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to reach his or her tongue to the hard palate during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly -Is the strength normal? -If patient presents with one-sided  weakness of tongue (or lips), he or she is more likely to have food become lodged or pocketed in the oral cavity on the weaker side -Following food and liquid trials, examine weaker side of the oral cavity for residueAbnormalities of mandibular function may indicate damage to CN V(17) -Is the patient able to maintain jaw closure at rest? -Is ROM normal? -Adequate mandibular ROM is necessary for the patient to adequately masticate solid foods -Is strength normal?  -Is the mandible structurally intact? -Patients with head and neck cancer (especially base of the tongue cancers) might have had reconstructive surgeries altering anatomy of the jaw –Hard palate(32) -Is the hard palate intact? -Any signs of fistulas, fissures, or scarring? -Are the height and width normal? -Any prostheses present? -Is the coloration normal?Abnormalities of the soft palate (velum) may indicate damage to CN XII(17,32) -Is the coloration normal (should be pink and white)? -Any signs of cleft or bifid uvula? -Does the palate elevate sufficiently and equally on both sides? -Use a flashlight to see to the back of the patient’s throat during sustained phonation of the syllable /a/ and repeated phonation of /a-a-a/(17) -Does the patient sound hyper-  or hyponasal during conversational speech? -Place a small mirror under the patient’s nose during production of nonnasal sounds; fogging or clouding might indicate nasal emission, which would necessitate a referral to the otolaryngologist –Teeth(31,32) -Are there any missing teeth? -Are the teeth in good repair? -Does the patient wear partial or full dentures? -If the patient is edentulous, inquire if the patient has dentures at home; if family is able to bring dentures in, reexamine mastication with dentures present -Patients who are edentulous may still be able to eat a regular diet; each patient is different -Is there a significant over-  or underbite?
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, and cognition should be evaluated by the SLP prior to initiation of an endoscopic evaluation(1) –Patients who are unable to maintain adequate attention or arousal are not appropriate for an endoscopic evaluation –The patient can participate in an endoscopic evaluation if he or she is able to follow verbal or nonverbal commands and is cooperative and compliant with respect to swallowing or attempting to swallow food and/or liquid trials
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: In order to observe swallowing function in a FEES or FEESST, trials of food and liquid are given to the patient(3) –The food and liquid trials should not be translucent, red, or brown in order to achieve adequate visibility during the

contraindications precautions: Types of dysphagia: Oral dysphagia, pharyngeal dysphagia, or oropharyngeal dysphagia(16) -If the SLP suspects esophageal dysphagia, a referral to gastroenterology is appropriate for further management
Severity of dysphagia: Mild, moderate, severe, profound
-Mild: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 23 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are spontaneously cleared; patient coughs appropriately to clear pharyngeal residue(16)
-Moderate: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 35 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are cleared given a cue; patient coughs to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue given a cue(16)

-Severe: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 510  seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are not able to be cleared; patient does not cough appropriately to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue; also may have difficulty managing his or her own secretions(16) -Profound: term usually reserved for patients who present with no apparent swallow response, as well as minimal ability to protect the airway
Patients do not always fit into these categories of dysphagia severity; it is also appropriate for the SLP to classify a patient’s dysphagia as minimal, mild-moderate,  or moderate-severe(16)

V ocal fold findings might include: -Arytenoid damage (including erythema, edema, erosion, or granularity)(27) -Can indicate gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) or laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR)(27) -V ocal fold edema/irritation(7,27) -Can indicate GERD or LPR(27) -V ocal fold immobility(7)
The recommendations for oral feeding are generally based on the severity of dysphagia and overall risk of aspiration(16)

Although recommendations are made on an individual basis, common recommendations include: -Normal swallow: If the patient appears to have normal swallowing function, the patient is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid(16) -Minimal impairment: If the patient appears to have minimally impaired swallowing function, the patient is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the independent use of one or more compensatory strategies(16)  -Mild impairment: If the patient appears to have mildly impaired swallowing function, the patient is usually safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the use of one or more compensatory strategies; this type of patient generally requires cueing up to 10% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(16) -Mild-moderate  impairment: If the patient appears to have mild-moderately impaired swallowing function, the patient will require some modification of his or her diet and will require the use of one or more compensatory strategies; this type of patient generally requires cueing up to 25% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(16) -Moderate impairment: If the patient appears to have moderately impaired swallowing function, the patient will require modification of his or her diet, as well as direct supervision during meals; patient will require frequent cues to use one or more compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient may require nonoral nutritional or hydrational support(16) -Moderate-severe  impairment: If the patient appears to have moderate-severely  impaired swallowing function, the patient will require significant modification of his or her diet, as well as 1:1 assistance during meals with constant cues to use compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient will require nonoral nutritional or hydrational support(16) -Severe impairment: If the patient appears to have severely impaired swallowing function, the patient should be placed on NPO status (nothing by mouth) with nonoral means of nutritional and hydrational support; any food or liquid trials should be given by the SLP only during therapy sessions(16) -Profound impairment: Patients with a profound impairment of swallowing will not be appropriate for any food, liquid, or medication by mouth; these patients are generally not appropriate for therapeutic trials of food or liquid with SLP; the
patient’s oral cavity should be aggressively cleaned and suctioned by nursing every 23 hours to prevent infection(16)
For detailed information on dysphagia therapy, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Patients with the diagnosis of dysphagia may be at risk for aspiration. Swallowing precautions/feeding guidelines should be posted at bedside and caregivers, family members, and nursing staff should be educated regarding patient’s risk of aspiration ›Diagnosis/results of assessment:  Following an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing, the SLP will state whether or not the patient has dysphagia.(1,30) Generally, the SLP will make a statement regarding the type and severity of dysphagia.(14) If the patient does have dysphagia, the SLP will also make a statement and recommendation regarding oral feedings as well as expected treatment plan(1,16,30)
In addition to diagnosing dysphagia, endoscopic evaluations of the laryngopharyngeal structures can assist with the diagnosis of vocal fold dysfunction(7)
Treatment plan: The treatment plan might include recommendations for direct, indirect, compensatory, or facilitative dysphagia therapy(30)
contraindications precautions.general: Following an endoscopic evaluation of swallowing, the SLP will state whether or not the

assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the successful treatment of dysphagia(32) Referral to gastroenterologist for patients in whom esophageal dysphagia is suspected(31,32) Referral to neurologist for patients with dysphagia who do not have a known underlying diagnosis(32) Referral to pulmonologist for patients who appear to have poor respiratory status and/or function(32) Referral to ENT for patients with apparent vocal fold dysfunction and/or irritation/damage(7,27,31) Referral to nutrition services/dietician for patients with poor oral intake or those at risk for malnutrition(30,32) Referral to physical and/or occupational therapy for patients with poor posture, difficulty sitting up in the bed or chair, or difficulty feeding themselves(32)
treatment summary: See Indications for procedure  and Guidelines for procedure , above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A .

patient education: Information on dysphagia for patients and family members is available on the ASHA website, https://www.asha.org/public/ speech/swallowing/
Information on endoscopic evaluations of swallowing for patients and family members is available on the ASHA website at https://www.asha.org/public/speech/swallowing/endoscopy/ Note
